newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: SIMEX Eurodollars end down despite U.S.-Iraq news.
newsitem.headline: SIMEX Eurodollars end down despite U.S.-Iraq news.

text.p: SIMEX Eurodollar interest rate futures saw a volatile day on Tuesday, falling first on talk the U.S. Federal Reserve is mulling a bigger-than-expected rate hike and then recovering on news of the U.S. missile attack on Iraq.
The benchmark September contract finally finished sharply down at 94.26 against its previous IMM close at 94.34 and just off the day's low of 94.25.

"The story of the day was the Eurodollars," said one dealer with a U.S. commission house. "There was the Wall Street Journal report and then the U.S. launch of missiles and that made for quite a volatile day," he said.

The Wall Street Journal reported in its Tuesday edition that U.S. Federal Reserve policy makers were mulling a bigger-than-expected interest rate increase unless clear signs of slower growth emerge in the next three weeks.
Dealers said the report sent the September Eurodollar contract crashing to the day's low but it rebounded slightly on news of the U.S. launch of missiles in Iraq.
"But at the end of the day, the market concluded that a launching of missiles isn't going to stop the Fed so the Eurodollars were sold back down," another dealer said.
Elsewhere, Euroyen interest rate futures also finished weaker, partly due to sentiment that a U.S. rate hike would give the Bank Of Japan room to raise rates.
The sell-off was also exacerbated by market views that a further escalation of U.S.-Iraq tension would push the yen down against the dollar and drive U.S. short-term rates higher.
Japanese government bond futures ended at the day's low on news of the U.S. move against Iraq.
The September contract ended weaker at 122.05 against its opening levels at 122.54. -- Valerie Lee (65 8703080)
